body: Let's keep issue tracking in Issues.

High level design proposal:

* We introduce some sort of node oracle interface, with a method like `ExpectedState readState(LeakNode node)`, `ExpectedState` being an enum of `UNKNOWN, DEAD, ALIVE`
* We provide an API for registering a set of oracles. Those will run with the analysis service
* We provide a default set of standard oracles: Fragments / Activities / Services can be created / destroyed, views can be attached / detached. Application stays for ever, same with a bunch of other classes.
* We pass each node of the leak trace through the set of oracles, trying to eliminate as many "unknown" as possible.
* we apply the formula to simplify: if element dead, all elements further should be dead. if element alive, all elements before should be alive
* We figure out some way to display that in the string and in display leak activity. I'm wondering if we should also display the exact elements that got matches as well, with their rules, to make it very clear.
Instead of just "red / green", the display should also highlight the places where the leak might be. It's really on the field part of a set of rows of the leaktrace.

issue.title: Added more structured information to LeakTraceElement

repository.name: leakcanary
repository.description: A memory leak detection library for Android.

issue.body:
This will be needed for #727

* New structured description for references: LeakReference(type, name, value)
* Added class hierarchy to LeakTraceElement
* LeakTraceElement.fields (String) is deprecated, replaced with fieldReferences (LeakReference)
* LeakTraceElement.referenceName and LeakTraceElement.type are deprecated, replaced with LeakTraceElement.reference
* LeakTraceElement.className is deprecated, replaced with LeakTraceElement.classHierarchy.get(0)

body: Also, we can add a resource resolver, e.g. mID on a view could show the resource name instead of int value.

issue.title: Helping find the cause of a leak

repository.name: leakcanary
repository.description: A memory leak detection library for Android.

issue.body:
* Introduced Reachability and Reachability.Inspector which we use to determine the possible leak causes. AndroidReachabilityInspectors has a set of default inspectors.
* New API: `refWatcherBuilder.reachabilityInspectorClasses()`
* LeakTrace display has been revamped to surface that information and simplified, both the string version and the UI version.
* Added a second example leak to the sample app
* Added helper methods to LeakTraceElement

Fixes #727

![screenshot_1529735581](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/557033/41806592-b834a844-7675-11e8-8cf4-bb3462fab118.png)

Welcome and thank you for reporting an issue!

First:

- Confirm that you are using the latest version of LeakCanary (see https://github.com/square/leakcanary/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md)
- Verify that your issue hasn't already been reported by searching over all issues: https://github.com/square/leakcanary/issues?q=is%3Aissue.

What kind of issue is this?

 - *Question*: This issue tracker is not the place for questions. If you want to ask how to do
   something, or to understand why something isn't working the way you expect it to, use Stack
   Overflow: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/leakcanary.

 - *Help me fix a leak?*: Please do not file an issue.
   Instead, read here: https://github.com/square/leakcanary/#how-do-i-fix-a-memory-leak
 
 - *Leak analysis failed*: if it's an OutOfMemoryError, no need to report it. See https://github.com/square/leakcanary/wiki/Future#low-memory-leak-analysis

 - *Bug report*: If youâ€™ve found a bug, spend the time to write a failing test. Bugs with tests get fixed.
   Hereâ€™s an example: https://gist.github.com/swankjesse/981fcae102f513eb13ed
   
 - *Feature Request*: Start by telling us what problem youâ€™re trying to solve. Donâ€™t send pull requests to implement
   new features without first getting our support. Sometimes we leave features out on purpose to keep the project small.
